Notes: Students finish 9-year compulsory basic education at ~age 14-15 and then choose general secondary or vocational pathways.
Students enter diversified upper secondary tracks (academic or technical) after completing lower secondary at ~15.

AgeEstimationMethod: Converted from grade (end of lower secondary ≈ 15)
Notes: After basic secondary (grade 9, age ~15), students enter upper secondary with specialized tracks (e.g., bachillerato or technical programs).
No national separation into different school types; all students attend comprehensive high schools (ability grouping occurs within schools, not via separate tracks).
At age 10, pupils are split into different lower-secondary school types (academic Gymnasium vs. general NMS).
Students finish 6-year primary school at ~12 and enter secondary streams (general, technical, vocational); first 2-year cycle is common orientation:contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}.
After grade 7 (~age 14), national exams determine entry into selective high schools vs. other schools:contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}.
General academic upper secondary is standard; at ~15 some students opt for technical high school programs, though only ~11% do:contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}.
After primary, the Primary School Assessment exam at ~age 12 places students into either general secondary schools or vocational/applied secondary tracks:contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}.
No nationwide separation into different school types; students remain in comprehensive high schools (with course-level grouping by ability in later grades).

Most cantons stream pupils at the transition to lower secondary (~age 12) into different ability-based school tracks:contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}; a few cantons track later or offer integrated classes.

GradeOrStage: Upper secondary (last 2 years of high school)
Notes: First 2 years of secondary education are common; in the final 2 years (ages 16–18) students enter either academic (scientific-humanist) or vocational tracks:contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}.

After completing basic secondary (grade 9), typically at 15, students enter two-year upper secondary programs with various tracks (academic or technical) leading to different “Bachiller” diplomas:contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}.
After 9th grade (~age 15), students choose an academic or technical track in the diversified secondary cycle (grades 10–11).

While most students remain in comprehensive basic school until 15, an elite subset can transfer to 8-year gymnázium at age ~11 (after Grade 5):contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}. (Main tracking into vocational vs academic occurs after basic school at ~15.)

At the end of primary (usually age 10), pupils are placed into different secondary school types (e.g., Gymnasium, Realschule, Hauptschule) based on performance. *Note:* Two states delay selection until age ~12.
No tracking in Denmark’s Folkeskole (comprehensive basic school). At ~15 (after Grade 9), students choose between academic gymnasium or vocational upper secondary programs.
Secondary (edad 14–18) offers academic, technical, and vocational tracks:contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10}. Students typically choose/are assigned a track upon entering secondary at ~14.

Compulsory ESO (lower secondary) ends at 16. After that, students either pursue the two-year academic Bachillerato or enroll in vocational training (Formación Profesional):contentReference[oaicite:11]{index=11}.
No tracking during nine-year comprehensive basic school (ages 7–16). At ~15–16, after Grade 9, students enter either general upper secondary school (Gymnasium) or vocational school.
No streaming during comprehensive basic education (ages 7–16). At ~16, after 9th grade, students choose either academic upper secondary (lukio) or vocational college (ammattioppilaitos).

After the common lower secondary collège (ending around 14–15), students are formally tracked at lycée entry (~15). They enter either a general/technological lycée or a vocational lycée program:contentReference[oaicite:13]{index=13}.

No nationwide tracking policy (most secondary schools are comprehensive until 16). However, in parts of England and Northern Ireland, pupils take the 11-plus exam at age 11 for placement into selective grammar schools:contentReference[oaicite:14]{index=14}.
No formal tracking until completion of basic education (grade 9). At ~15, students may enter general high school or vocational education. (Regional disparities exist.)
Compulsory Gymnasio (lower secondary) ends at 15. Students then either attend general academic Lyceum or enroll in vocational upper secondary school (EPAL):contentReference[oaicite:15]{index=15}.
After básico (lower secondary, ends ~age 15), students enter the diversificado stage, choosing academic tracks (e.g., Bachillerato) or technical/vocational programs.

No separate school types until after junior secondary. At ~15 (Form 4), many schools stream students into Arts, Business, or Science streams for the senior secondary years:contentReference[oaicite:16]{index=16}.

Compulsory elementary school (grades 1–8) ends at ~14. Students then enter four-year secondary schools of different types (gymnasium, technical, vocational, art) based on Grade 8 results:contentReference[oaicite:17]{index=17}.

Selective academic tracks begin as early as age 10. High-performing students can enter 8-year academic gymnázium after grade 4:contentReference[oaicite:18]{index=18}. (Most students, however, remain in general school until the standard tracking at 14.)

After junior secondary (Grade 9, ~age 15), students choose between general senior high school (SMA) and vocational senior high (SMK). This first selection at ~15 is noted as a key decision point:contentReference[oaicite:19]{index=19}.

No tracking during Junior Cycle (up to ~15). After the Junior Certificate exams (age ~15), students choose among Leaving Certificate pathways – the traditional (academic) Leaving Cert, Leaving Cert Vocational, or Leaving Cert Applied (vocational) – for the senior cycle (ages 16–18).
No tracking in Iceland’s compulsory education (grades 1–10). At ~16, upon entering upper secondary, students choose between academic college-preparatory programs and various vocational programs.

Comprehensive lower secondary through grade 9. In upper secondary (grades 10–12, starting ~15), students are channeled into academic, technological, or vocational strands leading to different types of matriculation certificates.

GradeOrStage: Upper secondary (Scuola secondaria II grado start)
Notes: Tracking occurs at the end of lower secondary (middle school). At ~14, after grade 8, students choose among distinct high school types – academic liceo, technical institute, or vocational institute:contentReference[oaicite:20]{index=20}.

An exit exam at the end of primary school (~age 12) assigns students to different types of secondary schools. Selective “High Schools” (including technical high schools) offer four- to five-year programs starting at age 13–14, while others attend all-age or junior high schools. Thus, effectively, streaming occurs with the Grade 6 exam (11–12) which determines the secondary pathway:contentReference[oaicite:21]{index=21}.

After 10th grade (~age 16), students in Jordan choose either the academic (general) secondary track or the vocational track leading to the Tawjihi (secondary leaving exam). No earlier formal tracking (basic education is common).

Compulsory lower secondary (junior high) ends at 15. At that point, students take high school entrance exams and choose between academic senior high schools and vocational high schools. Roughly 20% of Japanese 15–18-year-olds attend vocational upper secondary programs:contentReference[oaicite:22]{index=22}.
After grade 9 (~age 15), students either continue in general secondary school (grades 10–11) or enter technical/vocational colleges. This is the first formal separation point in the system.

Formal national tracking is limited. After lower secondary (Grade 9, age ~15), some students enter vocational training streams or specialized upper secondary programs, but most continue in general upper secondary. No earlier streaming in the basic education (Grades 1–9).

After middle school (grade 9, ~age 15), students enter either an academic high school or a vocational high school. Only about 17% of upper-secondary students were in vocational high schools as of 2016:contentReference[oaicite:23]{index=23}.

After completing lower secondary at ~age 15, students choose between general upper secondary (gymnasium) and vocational secondary schools. There is no earlier formal tracking in primary/lower secondary.

Basic education in Lithuania lasts until grade 10 (age ~16). After that, students enter upper secondary: either a general academic track (leading to Matura after grades 11–12) or vocational training. Thus, first selection is at ~16, upon completion of grade 10:contentReference[oaicite:24]{index=24}.
Compulsory basic education (grades 1–9) is comprehensive. At ~15, after grade 9, students choose between general upper secondary school and secondary vocational education programs.

The first three years of secondary (Forms 1–3) are general. In the last three years (Forms 4–6, starting ~15), Macao’s schools often split students into science, commerce, or arts streams. There is no formal tracking before Form 4.

All students follow common basic education through lower secondary (collège) ending around 15. At upper secondary (lycée), beginning ~15–16, they choose between general (academic) streams and technical/vocational streams.
No early tracking; after gymnasium (grade 9, age ~15) students either enter lyceum (academic high school) or vocational school. This is the first formal differentiation in the Moldovan system.

Lower secondary (secundaria) ends at 15. For upper secondary (ages 15–18), students choose between general preparatoria and technical/professional bachillerato programs:contentReference[oaicite:25]{index=25}. This is the first major tracking point.

Following 9 years of compulsory primary/lower secondary, typically completed by age 14–15, students enter upper secondary. They enroll either in general gymnasium or in vocational secondary schools at this stage.

Traditionally, Malta has a high-stakes exam at age 11+ that determines entry into elite Junior Lyceums versus general Secondary schools:contentReference[oaicite:26]{index=26}. Thus, able students are tracked into more academic schools from age 11. (Reforms to replace this system with middle schools have been underway, but the 11+ selection remained influential into the 2010s.)
After completing 9 years of basic school (~age 15), students choose between general secondary (gymnasium) and various vocational secondary programs. There is no earlier formal tracking.

Mongolia’s general secondary education was extended to 12 years. No formal tracking occurs until after lower secondary. Around age 15, upon entering upper secondary, students may choose specializations (science, humanities) or opt for vocational training. However, the system remains largely comprehensive until Grade 10.

Students follow a common curriculum through Form 3 (about age 15). At Form 4 (~16 years old), they are streamed into Arts or Science streams (and recently, other options) for the last two years of secondary:contentReference[oaicite:27]{index=27}. This streaming was historically rigid, but reforms are in progress to introduce more subject flexibility.

A national test in the final year of primary (age 11–12) and teacher advice determine secondary track placement. At ~12, pupils are routed into pre-vocational (VMBO), general (HAVO), or pre-university (VWO) secondary schools:contentReference[oaicite:28]{index=28}.

No tracking in compulsory basic schooling (through grade 10, age ~16). At ~16, students enter upper secondary and choose either an academic studies path or one of several vocational/technical training paths.

All students attend comprehensive secondary schools with a common core curriculum. Starting around age 15–16 (NCEA Levels 1–3), students select subject combinations (including vocational courses) but there is no division into separate school types.

After 9th grade (~age 15), Panamanian students enter the diversified secondary cycle. They choose among different tracks (academic sciences, commerce, technical, etc.). Earlier grades are common and untracked.

Secondary education in Peru lasts 5 years (ages ~12–17). The first three years have a common curriculum; in the final two years (typically starting ~15), students follow an academic or a technical track specialization. No separation into different schools, but curricular tracks begin in those last two years.

Under the K-12 system, all students complete a general junior high (Grades 7–10). At ~16, entering Grade 11, they must choose one of four Senior High School tracks (Academic, Technical-Vocational-Livelihood, Sports, or Arts & Design):contentReference[oaicite:29]{index=29}. This is the first formal streaming.

Poland recently returned to 8-year primary + 4-year secondary. At ~15 (after primary), students enter either a general academic liceum or a vocational technical school (technikum). Formerly, under the 1999–2017 system, the tracking point was after gimnazjum at ~16.

Compulsory education in Portugal now extends to 18, but tracking occurs at the start of upper secondary (~15). Students choose one of several paths in grades 10–12: scientific-humanities (academic), technological/professional (vocational), or artistic.

After completing nine years of basic education (~age 15), students enter educación media. The first year is often a core curriculum, then students pick a specialization (e.g., Social Sciences, Technical) in the final two years. There is no separate school tracking before this, aside from within-school ability grouping.

In the Palestinian education system, basic education lasts 10 years. At ~16 (grade 11), students choose either the academic stream (Scientific or Literary) or the vocational stream for the two-year upper secondary leading to the Tawjihi exam.

Secondary education (grades 10–12) in Qatar allows students to specialize in science, arts, or technology streams. This choice typically happens at ~16 (after a common Grade 10). Before that, preparatory education (to ~15) is standardized.

Compulsory general education in Azerbaijan lasts through grade 9 (age ~15). After that, students either continue in general secondary school (grades 10–11) or enroll in vocational education (lyceums/colleges). Thus, first selection is at ~15.
No country identified for code 'QUR'. (Code not recognized in provided list; skipped.)

After 8th grade (~age 14), students take a national exam which determines admission to different high schools. They then enter either an academic high school (theoretical or technological stream) or a vocational school. This is the first selection point:contentReference[oaicite:30]{index=30}.

Students complete 3 years of intermediate school by ~age 15. Secondary school (ages ~16–18) is more specialized: students choose between a science track, literature track, or technical/vocational secondary programs. No formal tracking before secondary (basic education is common).

Singapore historically streamed pupils at the end of Primary 3/4 (~age 9–10) into different ability bands (EM1/EM2/EM3):contentReference[oaicite:31]{index=31}. In secondary school (from age 12+), there is also Express/Normal (Academic/Technical) streaming based on the Primary 6 PSLE exam. (Subject-Based Banding reforms are now replacing some of these tiers.)
After 9th grade (~age 15), students enter the two-year Bachillerato, where they choose different modalities (e.g., General, Technical). No earlier formal tracking; basic education (1–9) is common.

Serbia has 8 years of compulsory primary school (ages ~7–14). At ~14, students enter secondary education by choosing a 4-year gymnasium (academic) or various 3- or 4-year vocational secondary schools. The choice at 14 is the first track differentiation.

High-achieving pupils can enter an 8-year gymnázium after grade 5 (age ~11):contentReference[oaicite:32]{index=32}. This early academic track removes them from regular basic school. Otherwise, the main tracking occurs at ~15, after 9th grade, when students choose between 4-year gymnázium, specialized secondary, or vocational school.

Slovenia’s 9-year basic school ends at ~15. At that point, students enroll in upper secondary programs: either 4-year gymnasium (general), 4-year technical secondary, 3-year vocational secondary, or other training programs. This choice at ~15 is the first formal separation into tracks.

Sweden has no tracking in compulsory comprehensive school (ages 7–16). At ~16, students enter gymnasium, choosing one of 18 national programs (either 6 university-preparatory or 12 vocational programs). This choice at upper-secondary entry is the first time students are formally divided by program.

After 9 years of compulsory education (ending ~age 15), students take exams for admission to either academic senior high schools or vocational high schools. This exam and placement at ~15 constitutes the first major tracking in Taiwan’s system.

Lower secondary (Matthayom 1–3) is common for all students (through ~age 15). At upper secondary (Matthayom 4–6, ages ~15–18), students choose either the general academic track or enroll in vocational secondary schools. This marks the first formal separation.

Tracking is effectively at the transition to upper secondary. After 8th grade (~age 14), students take a centralized exam that allocates them to different types of high schools: academically oriented Anatolian high schools, vocational/technical high schools, imam-hatip (religious) high schools, etc. Thus, 14 is the age of first selection into separate school tracks.

Uruguay’s compulsory basic cycle (6 years primary + 3 years lower secondary) ends at ~15. In the subsequent Diversified Bachillerato (upper secondary), students choose an orientation (Humanities, Science, Biology, Art or vocational tracks). This choice at ~15 is the first formal differentiation.

The U.S. does not segregate students into different secondary school types based on ability or vocation. All students attend comprehensive high schools (generally ages 14–18). Some within-school ability grouping and course-level tracking occur (e.g., honors/AP, remedial classes), but there is no systemic early tracking into separate institutions.

Uzbekistan mandates 9 years of general education. At ~15, after grade 9, students must enroll either in an academic lyceum (3-year academically oriented upper secondary) or a vocational college (2–3 year professional education). This reform (since ~1990s) means formal streaming happens at age 15.

Basic schooling (primary + lower secondary) is comprehensive through about age 15 (end of Grade 9). For upper secondary (grades 10–12, ages ~15–18), students either attend academic high schools preparing for the university-track graduation exam, or they may opt for vocational secondary programs. Thus, the first track choice is at ~15:contentReference[oaicite:33]{index=33}.
